TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesdays: The "Let's Do the Time Warp Again" Edition

Articles.Content:
As mentioned, it's going to flow evenly between each stage (based on the active engine and placement of the decoupler). It shouldn't be a problem for rockets, it also shouldn't be an issue for planes in NEAR and presumably the new stock aero.

That wasn't the point I was making; we can't move tanks around stages. Using decouplers is inelegant solution and is a brute force method; we now can't use any other part, because fuel will be consumed regardless of whether any other fuel-blocking part is added.

That might not be entirely what was intended? Unsure.

Even so, this is really more related to aircraft. I presume the same fuel drain logic won't be added to liquid+oxidiser engines. At least I hope not. Otherwise it's going to make rocket construction somewhat painful.

Drawing fuel evenly doesn't automatically mean the COM won't move, either. It will (or won't) depending on where small and large tanks are placed, relative to the COM. Not sure that's really making things more predictable here, either.

Regardless, it's the answer to a question created by and as a function of the new aero model, more than an actually needed function.

Controlling fuel flow actually becomes even more useful if wings with tanks are added. Some kind of 'pump' control, just in general would be very useful - and might be a more elegant solution that provides better control for both aircraft, and complex-staged rockets alike.
